summary:
[Dedication page] 
for the boy who lived. 
thank you for inspiring me to be 
the girl who survived. 
you may have 
a lightning...
text:
[Dedication page]
for the boy who lived.
thank you for inspiring me to be
the girl who survived.
you may have
a lightning bolt
to show for it,
but my body is a
lightning storm.
source: The Princess Saves Herself in This One by Amanda Lovelace

reblog.comment: The Princess Saves Herself in This One by Amanda Lovelace

summary: Unpopular Harry Potter Opinion - Always
title: Unpopular Harry Potter Opinion - Always
body:
“Always” isn’t romantic. I see it all over Pinterest as I peruse wedding inspiration and it confuses the heck out of me. Clinging to unrequited love for your entire life isn’t healthy or aspirational for a couple. It’s a fascinating part of Snape’s characterization and a driving force for much of the character’s decision making but the way it has evolved to be this romantic mantra people repeat gives me the creeps. 

There is a lot about “Always” that make for an incredible story arch - Snape’s regret over actions that led to the falling apart of a valuable friendship that he might have hoped could one day be romantic + his regret over actions that directly led to the death of a woman he held deep and meaningful feelings for. His positive actions following are fueled by this regret and his internal whispers of “what could have been.”

But never forget part of “what could have been” was happily celebrating the death of his crush’s husband and child so he might have another chance. Sure, he went to Dumbledore as soon as he found out the Potters were the target, but his original ask was to save her alone, not the whole family. He reverted to thr larger request when it became clear that would be the option most likely to be acted upon by the Order. If the option to save Lily alone existed… you can guarantee that is the one he would have taken. 

Yes, he “Always” loved her. But that love wasn’t ever, yet alone “Always”, healthy.

There is a lot about “Always” that make for an incredible story arch - Snape’s regret over actions that led to the falling apart of a valuable friendship that he might have hoped could one day be romantic + his regret over actions that directly led to the death of a woman he held deep and meaningful feelings for. His positive actions following are fueled by this regret and his internal whispers of “what could have been.”

But never forget part of “what could have been” was happily celebrating the death of his crush’s husband and child so he might have another chance. Sure, he went to Dumbledore as soon as he found out the Potters were the target, but his original ask was to save her alone, not the whole family. Clinging to unrequited love for your entire life isn’t healthy or aspirational for a couple. It’s a fascinating part of Snape’s characterization and a driving force for much of the character’s decision making but the way it has evolved to be this romantic mantra people repeat gives me the creeps. 

There is a lot about “Always” that make for an incredible story arch - Snape’s regret over actions that led to the falling apart of a valuable friendship that he might have hoped could one day be romantic + his regret over actions that directly led to the death of a woman he held deep and meaningful feelings for. His positive actions following are fueled by this regret and his internal whispers of “what could have been.”

But never forget part of “what could have been” was happily celebrating the death of his crush’s husband and child so he might have another chance. Sure, he went to Dumbledore as soon as he found out the Potters were the target, but his original ask was to save her alone, not the whole family. If the option to save Lily alone existed… you can guarantee that is the one he would have taken.

trail.content:
“Always” isn’t romantic. I see it all over Pinterest as I peruse wedding inspiration and it confuses the heck out of me. Clinging to unrequited love for your entire life isn’t healthy or aspirational for a couple. It’s a fascinating part of Snape’s characterization and a driving force for much of the character’s decision making but the way it has evolved to be this romantic mantra people repeat gives me the creeps. 

There is a lot about “Always” that make for an incredible story arch - Snape’s regret over actions that led to the falling apart of a valuable friendship that he might have hoped could one day be romantic + his regret over actions that directly led to the death of a woman he held deep and meaningful feelings for. His positive actions following are fueled by this regret and his internal whispers of “what could have been.”

But never forget part of “what could have been” was happily celebrating the death of his crush’s husband and child so he might have another chance. Sure, he went to Dumbledore as soon as he found out the Potters were the target, but his original ask was to save her alone, not the whole family. He reverted to thr larger request when it became clear that would be the option most likely to be acted upon by the Order. If the option to save Lily alone existed… you can guarantee that is the one he would have taken. 

Yes, he “Always” loved her. But that love wasn’t ever, yet alone “Always”, healthy.
